content: The MORE Act of 2009 terminates prohibitions on expenditures for offshore oil and gas leasing activities, revoking withdrawals of Federal submerged lands for exploration and production of oil and natural gas. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to require State approval for oil and natural gas leasing within 25 miles of a State's coastline. Repeal of State approval law has no effect. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to require State approval for oil and natural gas leasing within 25 miles of a State's coastline. Royalties from qualified oil and gas leases on submerged lands within State boundaries will have 12.5 percent deposited in the Treasury. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to require State approval for oil and natural gas leasing within 25 miles of a State's coastline. Royalties from qualified oil and gas leases on submerged lands within State boundaries will have 12.5 percent deposited in the Renewable Energy Reserve and 75 percent paid to producing States. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to require State approval for oil and natural gas leasing within 25 miles of a State's coastline. Royalties from qualified oil and gas leases on submerged lands will be distributed with 5 percent to the Renewable Energy Reserve, and 90 percent to producing States. For leased tracts partially within a State's seaward boundaries, royalties will be a percentage of the total amounts. The curr_chunk defines terms related to programs, plans, lease sales, and activities on the Outer Continental Shelf, including the definition of a "producing State" as an Adjacent State with leased tracts that generate royalties. The term "State" includes Puerto Rico and other US territories. A "qualified oil and gas lease" is a lease granted after the Maximize Offshore Resource Exploration Act of 2009 for oil and gas development. The curr_chunk amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to establish State Seaward Boundaries by extending lines indicated on maps for each Outer Continental Shelf region. It does not apply to the treatment under section 105 of the Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act of 2006 regarding Outer Continental Shelf revenues. SEC. 5. RENEWABLE ENERGY RESERVE. The "Renewable Energy Reserve" is established for budgetary purposes, consisting of deposits to promote cleaner energy resources, energy-efficient products, and renewable energy technologies.
